earliestArticle.dc:abstract: Epilepsy is heritable, yet few causative gene mutations have been identified, and thus far no human epilepsy gene mutations have been found to produce seizures in invertebrates. Here we show that mutations in prickle genes are associated with seizures in humans, mice, and flies. We identified human epilepsy patients with heterozygous mutations in either PRICKLE1 or PRICKLE2. In overexpression assays in zebrafish, prickle mutations resulted in aberrant prickle function. A seizure phenotype was present in the Prickle1-null mutant mouse, two Prickle1 point mutant (missense and nonsense) mice, and a Prickle2-null mutant mouse. Drosophila with prickle mutations displayed seizures that were responsive to anti-epileptic medication, and homozygous mutant embryos showed neuronal defects. These results suggest that prickle mutations have caused seizures throughout evolution.
earliestArticle.dc:creator: Tao H
earliestArticle.dc:title: Mutations in prickle orthologs cause seizures in flies, mice, and humans.

evidence.dc:description: Even though the Drosophila model showed seizures, the Drosophila has only one prickle gene but does not have homolog of specific PRICKLE2 of the human genome. Therefore, this experimental evidence does not support the disease association with PRICKLE2 gene.
evidence.rdfs:label: Drosophila model

evidence.dc:description: Even though the Drosophila model showed seizures, the Drosophila has only one prickle gene but does not have a homolog of specific PRICKLE2 of the human genome. Therefore, this experimental evidence does not support the disease association with PRICKLE2 gene.
Even though the mouse model showed an increased seizure phenotype by decreased seizure threshold for the induced seizure, it didn't show an increased spontaneous seizure.
evidence.rdfs:label: Mouse model

evidence.dc:description: Even though the mouse model showed an increased seizure phenotype by decreased seizure threshold for the induced seizure, it didn't show an increased spontaneous seizure. Therefore, this experimental evidence does not support the human complex neurodevelopmental disorder phenotype.
The zebrafish model phenotype is not relevant to human phenotype (complex neurodevelopmental disorder phenotype)

dc:description: *PRICKLE2* was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant complex neurodevelopmental disorder [MONDO:0100038] in 2011. (Tao et al., PMID: 21276947). At the time of this curation, there were no other single-gene disorders associated with this gene. This curation is based on this disease entity only. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data. 4 variants (missense, nonsense and frameshift) that have been reported in 4 probands in 3 publications (PMIDs: 21276947, 29390993, 34092786) are included in this curation. The mechanism of pathogenicity appears to be LOF, but it is still unclear. In summary, there is limited evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. Although more evidence is needed to support a causal role, no convincing evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease relationship. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Epilepsy Gene Curation Expert Panel on the meeting date 12/06/2022 (SOP Version 9).
